title: R43142
content: The annual Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations bill includes funding for agencies and programs in three separate federal departments. Title I provides funding for Department of the Interior agencies, Title II for the Environmental Protection Agency, and Title III for agencies in other departments and related entities. This report focuses on FY2014 enacted appropriations for these agencies. The report compares FY2014 enacted appropriations for Department of the Interior agencies, Environmental Protection Agency, and other related entities with FY2013 and FY2012 appropriations. Appropriations are complex due to large budget requests with numerous changes for congressional consideration. The report does not provide detailed information on specific agencies or accounts. The report does not provide detailed account-level information or information on budgetary reorganizations. None of the 12 regular appropriations bills for FY2014 had been enacted as of October 1, 2013. No interim continuing resolution had been enacted to provide appropriations for projects and activities covered by the bills. Contact key policy staff for funding details for individual accounts or programs. During the government shutdown in October 2013, a short-term continuing resolution (CR) was enacted on October 17, 2013 (P.L. 113-46) to fund projects and activities at FY2013 levels. The CR provided exceptions for Wildland Fire Management and extended appropriations for FY2014 until January 18, 2014. Agencies were generally prohibited from spending funds in advance of appropriations during this time. During the government shutdown in October 2013, agencies were generally prohibited from spending funds in advance of appropriations. Exceptions allowed some agency functions to continue for emergencies. Agencies in the Interior bill developed plans for FY2014, summarizing activities that would cease and continue during a lapse in appropriations. Plans included the number of employees expected to be retained and furloughed. For example, a DOI overview plan estimated that 58,765 employees would be furloughed out of 72,562 in pay status. National Parks and Wildlife Refuges would be closed, and public access restricted during a lapse in appropriations. During a government shutdown, agencies in the Interior bill developed plans for FY2014, outlining activities that would cease and continue. Wildlife Refuge Systems would be closed, public access restricted, and nonemergency activities on public lands terminated. U.S. Geological Survey's scientific work would be halted, only emergency response activities conducted by the Office of Surface Mining. Bureau of Ocean Energy Management and Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement would ensure drilling safety, but renewable activities and five year plan work would be terminated. Bureau of Indian Affairs offices would suspend most activities, but required payments to beneficiaries would continue. Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians would maintain minimum operations to issue checks to beneficiaries. During a government shutdown in FY2014, agencies in the Interior bill developed plans outlining activities that would cease and continue. Bureau of Indian Affairs offices would suspend most activities, but required payments to beneficiaries would continue. Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians would maintain minimum operations to issue checks to beneficiaries. Additional details for each DOI agency were included in agency-specific plans. The cessation or curtailment of some activities and services, such as the closure of national park units, was controversial among some Members of Congress and the public. In FY2014, appropriations for agencies in the Interior bill varied widely due to agency responsibilities, funding sources, and priorities. Funding for a small subset of agencies accounted for most of the total, with three agencies receiving 60.1% of the total enacted appropriations. Additionally, more than three-quarters of the total appropriation was allocated to five agencies, including the EPA, Forest Service, and Indian Health Service. In FY2014, appropriations for DOI agencies varied widely, with the National Park Service and Bureau of Indian Affairs receiving nearly half of the total budget. The Forest Service and Indian Health Service also received significant funding, while several agencies had appropriations of less than $80 million each. The FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was $30.12 billion, a 1.5% increase from FY2013. This included various appropriations and reflected reductions under the President's sequester order. The FY2014 appropriation was a 6.4% increase from FY2013, excluding supplemental appropriations for disaster relief. The FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was $30.12 billion, a 1.5% increase from FY2013. This included increases and decreases for different agencies, with a total decrease of $217.8 million for all DOI agencies and a decrease of $278.4 million for EPA. Despite the overall decrease for DOI agencies, most received increased appropriations for FY2014. The Bureau of Indian Affairs received the largest dollar increase in appropriations for FY2014. The overall decrease in EPA appropriations reflected various changes in agency accounts, programs, and activities, with the biggest decrease in the State and Tribal Assistance Grants account. This decrease was mainly due to supplemental appropriations for disaster relief in FY2013. STAG grants include Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Fund capitalization grants for wastewater and drinking water infrastructure projects. The FY2014 appropriations for water infrastructure projects aimed to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act and meet health goals. The largest increase was for the Environmental Programs and Management account. The Forest Service and Indian Health Service saw significant funding boosts for wildfire suppression and clinical services, respectively. The FY2013 full-year appropriations and reimbursements for fire transfers, as well as supplemental appropriations for disaster relief, are detailed in data columns. The President's FY2014 request included funding for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies, with specific allocations for DOI agencies, EPA, and other entities. The President's FY2014 request for funding in Title III of the bill totaled $10.95 billion, with significant variations in appropriations across agencies. Three agencies - EPA, Forest Service, and Indian Health Service - accounted for over half of the total requested amount. DOI agency requests ranged from $71.5 million to $2.64 billion, with five agencies requesting over $1 billion each. The FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was $30.12 billion, exceeding the Administration's request of $29.91 billion. Nearly half of the $10.81 billion requested for DOI agencies was for the National Park Service and Bureau of Indian Affairs. The President's proposal included varied funding levels for different agencies, with the Forest Service receiving $4.84 billion and the Indian Health Service over $4 billion. Fourteen agencies would have received less than $80 million each, with six proposed at less than $10 million each. The FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies was $30.12 billion, exceeding the Administration's request of $29.91 billion. DOI agencies collectively received $336.5 million less than sought by the President, with the U.S. Geological Survey and Fish and Wildlife Service receiving significantly lower appropriations. In contrast, EPA and Related Agencies received higher appropriations than requested, with the Forest Service receiving the biggest increase for suppressing wildland fires. The FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies included $600.0 million for suppressing wildland fires. Most agencies in Title III received level or lower funding compared to the President's request. No bill for regular appropriations for FY2014 was introduced before October 1, 2013. The House Appropriations Committee began a markup of a draft FY2014 appropriations bill on July 31, 2013. The House and Senate released draft bills for FY2014 with differing total appropriations for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies. The House draft contained $21.71 billion in new appropriations offset by rescissions and transfers, totaling $24.34 billion. The Senate draft contained $30.84 billion, including emergency appropriations for Wildland Fire Management, $6.50 billion higher than the House total. The Senate Interior draft recommended higher levels than the House Interior draft for every agency within the bill except for DOI Departmental Offices. The largest dollar difference between the House and Senate Interior drafts was in the recommendations for EPA; the Senate Interior level of $8.48 billion was $2.96 billion (53.6%) more than the House Interior level of $5.52 billion. The FY2014 appropriation of $30.12 billion was $5.78 billion (23.7%) more than the House Interior draft total of $24.34 billion. The Senate Interior draft recommended higher levels of funding for every agency in the bill compared to the House Interior draft, except for DOI Departmental Offices. The largest dollar difference was for EPA, with an appropriation of $2.68 billion higher than the House Interior draft. Other agencies with significant increases included Fish and Wildlife Service, Indian Health Service, National Park Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, Smithsonian Institution, and Forest Service. Only DOI Departmental Offices would have received higher funding in the House Interior draft. The FY2014 appropriations for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies showed differences between the House and Senate drafts. The House draft had lower funding levels overall, with the largest gap for EPA. Only the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement received higher funding in the House draft. The House and Senate drafts for FY2014 appropriations for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies differed. The House draft had lower funding levels overall, with the largest gap for EPA. Only the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement received higher funding in the House draft. The Senate Interior Subcommittee total also includes a $600.0 million Wildfire Suppression Emergency Appropriation. Overall, the FY2014 appropriation for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies increased by $891.4 million (3.0%) over FY2012. DOI agencies and Related Agencies received increased appropriations, while EPA appropriations declined. In FY2014, DOI appropriations increased overall by $174.7 million (1.7%), mainly due to funding for Wildland Fire Management. EPA appropriations decreased by $249.4 million (3.0%), with the Hazardous Substance Superfund account experiencing the largest decline of $125.0 million.
